positive.review:
If you've played a [i]Far Cry[/i] game before, you know the drill: vast open world, outposts to capture, and a charismatic villain. [i]Far Cry Primal[/i]  takes that foundation, wipes the slate clean, and proves that the core formula is strong enough to thrive even without modern tech. This isn't just a [i]Far Cry[/i] game; it's a profound survival simulator draped in an action-adventure shell.

The most immediate thing that grabs you is the atmosphere. The valley of Oros feels truly alive. The developers brilliantly captured the sounds of a time before civilization: the crunch of snow underfoot, the distant, eerie bellow of a mammoth, and the quick rustle in the bushes that signals either prey or your imminent death.

This sensory detail is critical because it sells the feeling of vulnerability. You are not a super-soldier; you are Takkar, a hunter struggling to keep his tribe, the Wenja, from extinction. Every sunrise is a hard-won victory.

The shift to primitive weapons is a game-changer. Trading a sniper rifle for a longbow and a fragmentation grenade for a sack of angry bees forces you to be smart, tactical, and resourceful. Every spear you throw feels weighty, every arrow loosed requires commitment. There‚Äôs a visceral, hands-on satisfaction to crafting your arsenal from the bones and hides of the animals you hunt.

But the true star is the Beast Master mechanic. Taming a deadly predator‚Äîbe it a massive cave bear or a cunning jaguar‚Äîand having it fight loyally by your side is immensely gratifying. It transforms Takkar from a simple hunter into a force of nature. Scouting out an enemy camp with your owl companion before sending in your sabretooth cat to cause chaos is peak gaming satisfaction.

Unlike modern [i]Far Cry[/i] games where the world resets after the story, Primal gives you a tangible sense of progression through your home village. As you rescue members of your scattered tribe and recruit specialists (like the shaman or the crafter), you literally see your home grow from a few crude huts to a bustling community.

This system gives real meaning to your resource gathering. You‚Äôre not just collecting skins for a wallet upgrade; you're collecting them to build a stronger shelter for your people. This sense of responsibility and seeing your community flourish adds a layer of depth and emotional investment that many other open-world games miss.

[i]Far Cry Primal[/i] is a unique entry that deserves recognition for its brave concept and flawless execution. It is gorgeous, brutal, deeply immersive, and its core mechanic of taming the wilds is simply fantastic. If you want an open-world experience that makes you feel connected to the land and the struggle for survival, grab your spear‚Äî[b]Oros is waiting.[/b]

i have played 3 and 4 100% and had a lot of fun. this one is different but ubisoft cooked with this. i liked everything about it especially the story. if you like far cry then i recommend this one as well
honorable mention : Fu*k Ubisoft
Boldest and most unconventional Far Cry Experience in the Franchise

I‚Äôve played about 15 hours, and I‚Äôm really enjoying Far Cry Primal. If you liked Assassin‚Äôs Creed Valhalla for its atmosphere and world building, this feels very similar, just set in a much older, prehistoric era.

The game has a strong tribal story line, satisfying melee combat, and a world that feels alive with animals, danger, and exploration.
Taming beasts is one of the best parts, and the whole environment feels immersive. It‚Äôs not a modern-style Far Cry with guns and vehicles, but the old-era theme works really well. The crafting, survival elements, and exploration keep the gameplay fun.

If you enjoy open-world adventure, primal weapons, and survival with a cinematic vibe, this is a solid game to play.

Pros:
Beautiful prehistoric world
Beast taming is fun
Great atmosphere and sound
Good exploration

Cons:

Story is simple
Combat can feel repetitive

Overall, a great experience if you love immersive worlds and old-era action.
You'd think a Far Cry game won't work without guns but Primal not only works, it also ends up being better than Far Cry 5 and 6 in several aspects.

Enemies are fun to play against, sometimes it can get repetitive but there are also a lot of melee weapons and lots of ways to get rid of the enemies. You can go stealthy but you can also go crazy and play however you want. All in all, it's a great game and I think you shouldn't sit this one out, especially when the game goes on sale.

Even though it carries the Far Cry name, Far Cry Primal feels like an entirely new experience‚Äîand an astonishingly impressive one at that. It‚Äôs crafted with a level of care and creativity that truly sets it apart from the rest of the series.

The scenarios are breathtaking, with wild, untamed landscapes that feel alive and dangerous in equal measure. The nature is immersive, full of detail and atmosphere, pulling you into a world that existed long before civilization. The tribes are deeply developed, each with its own culture, personality, and style, making every encounter feel meaningful and grounded.

Everything‚Äîfrom the environmental storytelling to the sound design‚Äîfeels thoughtful, deliberate, and remarkably polished. The amount of work poured into this game is obvious, and the result is a unique, memorable adventure that stands proudly on its own within the Far Cry franchise.

Love the Farcry series and this one really speaks to me. I always love using the bows in the games and having that be your main weapon in this one just hits the spot! I highly recommend this game if you love the stealth and primitive style. I love the other games as well but it's really cool having one specifically designed for that before gun feel.

This is still a great game. Definitely shows it's age but having played this when it was new I still find it so much fun. Good additions to gameplay and solid controls. Probably won't appeal to kids today but I had a great time. Just adding on there was an update in November 2025, 9 and a half years after it came out!
[h3]Awesome Game[/h3] I can only recommend this to anyone looking for fun gameplay with a good story. Hopefully, a FarCry Primal II will be released someday.

Honestly, I didn‚Äôt expect to enjoy Far Cry Primal as much as I did. At first, I thought the lack of guns and cars would make it feel empty compared to the other Far Cry games, but it‚Äôs actually the opposite. Once you get used to the primitive setting, the game pulls you in completely.

The world feels alive in a different way: you‚Äôre not chasing explosions or outposts full of soldiers, but surviving among mammoths, sabertooths, and rival tribes. The atmosphere is incredible. Dense forests, glowing caves, and the constant sound of animals hunting nearby. It‚Äôs one of those games where you can get lost just roaming around collecting resources and taming beasts.

Speaking of taming, controlling wild animals is easily the best part. Sending your sabertooth to maul enemies while you sneak in with a club never gets old. The progression system fits the prehistoric theme nicely, and the lack of modern technology makes every kill and every fire you start feel earned.

It‚Äôs not perfect. the story is simple, and some missions feel repetitive, but the immersion and setting make up for it. It‚Äôs more about living in that world than following a plot.

If you want something different from the usual shooter chaos and you like survival elements mixed with exploration, Far Cry Primal is absolutely worth playing even at its full price; however, it is often at a 90% discount, which is just unbelievably worth it.

No guns, no problem. Just spears, fire, and pure atmosphere.

Honestly, Far Cry Primal is the best Stone Age game ever. The world of Oros feels alive and dangerous, and the graphics still look amazing for a 2016 game. Hunting is SO satisfying ‚Äî tracking animals, crafting weapons, surviving against wolves‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just awesome. 

But the real fun? Taming beasts. It‚Äôs basically Pok√©mon: Caveman Edition. I went around catching every animal . And riding a mammoth or a sabretooth tiger? Absolute peak Stone Age power move üêòüêÖüî•. Once I had them all, I felt like a full-on prehistoric Beast Master.

I finished the game and seriously, I enjoyed every second of it. Hunting, exploring, surviving, taming beasts ‚Äî it‚Äôs pure primal fun. For a 2016 game, it still slaps. Worth every penny. 10/10 would grunt, throw spears, and ride a mammoth again.

Tldr: 6/10, lots of frustrating bugs years after release, got it for $5 in the sale, was worth the 5, probably wait for 90% off. Very ubisoft (IYKYK).

There is the skeleton of a potentially great game here dragged down by typical ubisoftisms. Very buggy, almost no attempt to patch any of them. 
Bugs so far: Clipped into terrain just by sliding down a hill, required a fast travel fix.
- LoS doesnt match the physical terrain polymesh making stealth a dice roll at best....
- And punished at the worst because AI can be forced to see you from anywhere regardless of wherre you are. (Bushes, caves, mountains, 2km away...)
- Friendly AI is so stupid it is suicidal, very helpful.
-Enemy AI is so smart it has satellite gps uplink.
Graphically its pretty, love the terrain (most of the time), but the UI is clunky and poorly optimised.
Upgrade balance seems pretty well spread and gated requiring risk reward from the player to earn upgrades.
Stealth is very poorly implemented and could learn a few things from... you know, ubisofts actually stealth based franchise....
Combat is very iffy sometimes with connecting shots and melee both on the player side and on the AI's.
This game feels better on expert difficulty but also feels worse. (Stealth is worse but the thrill is better).
The world feels alive with all the beasts and human factions interacting in different ways, great job. I love the fear that while you are hunting that you also can be hunted and never know.
With a few more tweaks, additions, balances and bug fixes Farcry Primal could be a great game, but for me theres a lot of negative here that dragged it down for me, still more positive than negative.
Oh and i love that they added the fire spread mechanic from farcry 2 and took lessons learnt with farcry 3.
Very long game. Outdated for 2025 but still very good!

Made me feel what it feels like to be a hunter and to be hunted. A true gem, loved every minute of this game.

[h1]Far Cry Primal Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
I expected a reskinned Far Cry checklist. I got the most unique entry in the series. Primal keeps the open world DNA but swaps guns for spears, adds survival vibes, and feels made with real care. It surprised me in the best way.

[hr]
[h1]What It Is[/h1]
A prehistoric Far Cry where you scavenge, hunt, and build up a tribe. No firearms, no modern gadgets. Movement is mostly on foot early, later you tame and ride beasts to cross the map faster. The change in tools and threats makes familiar Far Cry loops feel fresh.

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
Oros is gorgeous and dangerous. Forests, caves, and a snowy region with temperature management keep you thinking about survival. Wildlife is not window dressing. Wolves, big cats, and roaming herds create moments that feel organic. Running everywhere somehow never got old.

[hr]
[h1]Traversal and Beasts[/h1]
You start on foot, then unlock taming and mounts. Having a sabretooth or bear at your side changes how you approach camps and travel. The world size feels right, with enough risk on the roads to keep you alert between objectives.

[hr]
[h1]Combat and Stealth[/h1]
No guns, just bows, spears, clubs, and fire. I thought it would feel thin. It clicked. Stealth is satisfying, headshots with the bow feel great, and spears have weight. Some achievements pushed me to use different tools, which helped the combat shine instead of feeling limited.

[hr]
[h1]Quick Story Primer[/h1]
You play Takkar, a hunter who helps the Wenja tribe survive and grow while clashing with rival tribes across Oros. It is a straightforward rise from lone survivor to leader, focused on territory, tribe building, and the harshness of the land.

[hr]
[h1]Progression and Systems[/h1]
Gathering, crafting, village upgrades, and skill unlocks drive your growth. The village hub gives a clear sense of progress. Resource routes and hunting loops are engaging without turning into busywork.

[hr]
[h1]Achievements and Tips[/h1]
A fun list with some spicy asks. Permadeath mode exists. If you want to be safe, quitting to the menu before a fatal hit can save a run. Taming a fast mount early and investing in bow skills makes cleanup smoother.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] World feels handcrafted and alive
[*] Survival layer fits Far Cry better than expected
[*] Beast taming changes combat and travel
[*] Melee and bow play are simple but satisfying
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Story is serviceable rather than gripping
[*] Early game travel is slow until mounts unlock
[*] If you hate Ubisoft open worlds on principle, this will not convert you
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Recommended. Primal brings a real twist to the series without losing the fun. If you like Far Cry but want something that actually feels different, this is the one to try.

negative.review: It's Ubisoft, so idk what I was expecting.... Fun game when you can play it. Don't tab out or your OS will freeze and you have to reset your computer

For 2.99 it's a good reskin of the Far Cry formula in a unique setting, though only for a few of hours before things get repetitive. The melee combat is REALLY basic, with no blocking or dodging mechanics. Kind of annoying when things charge you. Makes combat with the human 'heavies' frustrating too. Main missions don't deveuate gameplay-wise much from clearing out camps in the open world; a limitation of the setting.

The environments are pretty with convincing roaming wildlife, and it's fun hunting, taming and riding some of them like the mammoths. Resource gathering and crafting/upgrading your base is engaging for a little while. After 10 hours you've seen everything the game has to offer, and there's no plot to drive you on in my opinion. When I got to a rival clan's human boss who tanks arrow shots, yet takes 90% health off you with a hit, sends 4 waves of fodder enemies at you between engagements it dawned on me how boring the combat, and clearly the 'boss' battles are and wasn't worth any more of my time unfortunately.

The Ull fight killed  the game for me.
Ubisoft, I kind of liked the game but you really tried and made it suck eventually.

I love far cry, and this game is fun. However the fact it WILL NOT LAUNCH if you're not online and have a ubisoft account, is the absolute killer of any reason to buy this game or any Ubisoft game in the future. I bought this to use on om steam deck while i travel. Didnt know about the mandatory account at the time. Tried to refund when i had less than two hours of play and was denied because i have and the game more than 2 weeks. I recommend never buying another ubisoft on pc while this is required.

Ubisoft Connect makes this game a huge waste, tried going through support today as I hadnt launched the game since 2018 only to be met with "I'd also like to inform you that your Steam account is separate from your game license as your license is tied to your Ubisoft account, so you may use the same Steam account but cannot use your license in multiple Ubisoft accounts." effectively soft-locking me from content I bought and decided to return too, never again.

can't play without an ubisoft account even tough my handlers is Valve. going to wait for the collective action against Ubisoft to see if i can collect on the courth judgement to get a refund outside of steam.
Game literally wont launch anymore, thanks Ubisoft Connect!

Really love the game but Ubisucks made it worse. No wonder there are only about 20% players got through the tutorial.

A total piece of crap, Game freezes every minute for over 10 sec. So it's unplayable. Tried diffrent "solutions" on diffrent support pages.none of them helped. And because I installed it a few weeks later then when i bought it, I couldn't get a refund. So if u buy, then install right away and try if it works on your pc. 

Last Far Cry i bought.
A lot of not enjoyable stuff in here. The mammoth riding missions are excruciating. And there are a lot of missions that make you slowly follow an owl or other stuff to make the game take longer.

The game itself is great, I've had more fun with it than anything else that I've played in the last few months. My first session had 0 performance issues besides one crash during a mission that resolved itself after a quick restart. The problem I face now is that the game is literally unplayable, and after much research there seems to be no fix. Since starting up the game for the second time, I've had constant stuttering and freezing in cutscenes, opening menus, options, the map, and even just walking around. I've done everything from uninstall the game, update drivers, validate files and nothing seems to be working. Really disappointed because the game has been a wonderful experience, and now I am unable to finish it. From what I can tell, this issue seems to be a common occurrence among the player base and not solely a me problem. I got the game on sale for relatively cheap, so I haven't lost big money or anything but save yourself the time and the money and don't buy it.

What a disgrace to its ancestors. The core gameplay loop basically consists of running around collecting leather, rocks, and leaves. If you‚Äôre not bored yet, great news ‚Äî there‚Äôs even more walking for you! The only difference is that now you‚Äôre an animal, and all you can do is fly or run. Still not bored enough? fuck ubisoft man

Some reviewers say, it¬¥s unlike any other Far Cry game. But it is. Far Cry without guns but with the usual Ubisoft slop. 

The gameplay is like it¬¥s setting. Stuck in 10.000 BC.The setting suggests innovation but hides the fact, that its a shallow hunting-and-gathering-amidths-tribal-wars timewaster. It speaks to the tribalistic instincts of us humans. Looting, gathering, survival, blood and guts.The tribals speak their own fictional language with bad grammar. Yes it¬¥s new, until you realise, it fails to convey any good story or lore. This is it¬¥s first sin. It is just spoken clich√© after clich√©, with some prehistoric mysticism. "You warrior, you kill many udam. You strong. Now drink soup of pee blud and dung. Go kill more udam for me. Become great warrior." 

Which brings me to questing: Sidequest seem varied enough to avoid getting bored quickly. But its just, gather this and that, protect or save villagers, kill enemies, destroy enemy villages, conquer enemy base for fast travel. Saved villagers are added to your village for miniscule rewards. Its really mostly a big numbersgame. Some quests just are awful. Without the side content the main story takes maybe 5 hrs. And it is also a prehistoric clich√©, where you take revange on the lesser human tribes. 
 (Sidenote: In FarCry 5, which I didn¬¥t recommend, there was a sidequest, where you have to gather dog poo. Guess what, here you have at one point gather... rhino shit. Or you play in dreams as the animals you hunt and its so.... without any meaning or sense. And the Urki questline tries to be funny, because Urki is a ancestor (?) of Hurk from the other games... but it borders on insult you as a gamer.)

The map is big and riddled with the usual questionmarks to unveil and nothing behind it. Random events provide sidequests, yes. But new locations are forgetable and only provide resources until you have no room in your backpack which is 90% of the time.. Quickly you forget the names of these locations and never visit them again. There are collectables but..they are another timewaster, with little to no reward. Besides the burden to collect em all.  47/100 Dashya hands gatherd. 3 until a reward. I still don¬¥t know what kind of the reward it was.

The world is pretty, but nothing special, At an early point you just don¬¥t see it anymore....its just there...you traverse it on your sabertoothed tiger and...welll, yeah...nothing more to it.

Combat is unsuprisingly fun. You exchange the handgun for a club, the rifle for a bow. End of story.

I struggle to recommend it. Another case for a neutral review option. Because in the sum it seems better than all its parts. I played through it, although I rushed at the last quests just to 100%.  That it because my Limbic System commanded me to kill and loot and fullfil my quest to eradicate the inferior tribes...  And i think the one occational female naked boob kept me playing. But I am not tribalistic enough to struggle through another playthrough on permadeath or something. At the end, I feel dissatisfied.

The game is not bad, but its requires FUCKING ubisoft connect launcher, which half of the times won't turn on. And the fix is to get a vpn.....
I will not fucking get vpn to log into this stupid app.
Everything ubisoft made should be avoided until they remove this shitty launcher
ubisoft connect stays running in the background after you have closed the game.
It's Ubisoft, so idk what I was expecting.... Fun game when you can play it. Don't tab out or your OS will freeze and you have to reset your computer
game wont run at all says fetal error, something about gamer profile and i cant be bothered to fix this

For 2.99 it's a good reskin of the Far Cry formula in a unique setting, though only for a few of hours before things get repetitive. The melee combat is REALLY basic, with no blocking or dodging mechanics. Kind of annoying when things charge you. Makes combat with the human 'heavies' frustrating too. Main missions don't deveuate gameplay-wise much from clearing out camps in the open world; a limitation of the setting.

The environments are pretty with convincing roaming wildlife, and it's fun hunting, taming and riding some of them like the mammoths. Resource gathering and crafting/upgrading your base is engaging for a little while. After 10 hours you've seen everything the game has to offer, and there's no plot to drive you on in my opinion. When I got to a rival clan's human boss who tanks arrow shots, yet takes 90% health off you with a hit, sends 4 waves of fodder enemies at you between engagements it dawned on me how boring the combat, and clearly the 'boss' battles are and wasn't worth any more of my time unfortunately.

So if u ever forget your ubisoft account or the launcher start with another account its fked u cant play
I bought it and refunded it cus for whatever reason the launcher decided to make new account and use lock in the game there
Now i need to painstakingly manuver the bad launcher just to play thx ubisoft never buying your games again

Do you play just to play? Then this game is fine, another grinding simulator with 90% of stuff that you get useless. Apart from that, Extreme difficulty, survival and permadeath(and especially all combined) is one of the worst representation for permadeath, and in general, as a challenge total bullshit that is not hard, but rather grindy, and unfair
You can have maximum 4 health bars instead of 6 in original, enemies deal so much more damage, some hobo by throwing his small rock at you will deal HALF of your damage, and if theres more than 1 enemy, chances are you will be killed within 5 seconds. SO not only ur hp is limited, which could be fine, BUT DAMAGE INCREASED TOO? Im not sure about enemies HP, but it felt like theyre tanks as well. Also this challenge cuts 80% of your gameplay by not allowing you to use melee combat, because if you will try, well, you will die, you of course can try to kill 2-3 enemies, but thats your limit, killing tanks for some reason unbearrably hard, but knifes killing them fast for some reason???
Stun and lack of cooldown of attacks from enemies WITH THIS CHALLENGE, is the insanest bullshit ever possible
So not only animals can kill you relatively quick, but they can do so without any cooldowns and also knocking you down. So you just have no chance to escape.
Also i had to play with Survivor vision whole game otherwise i wouldnt be able to collect anything, and the color game have is just killing my eyes.
If you want to play just once, good choice, if you want to 100% it, dont even try. Not only you would have to 100% original game, but then also complete the game on expert survival permadeath(which devs are mocking us by saying no one will do it, but with enough patience its easy). Advise, find save files, and do backup every.single.time. you complete a mission, activity ANYTHING, trust me, you will thank me for this.
2/10
like many steam games, this one also doesnt want to start a game and closes itself down before the game begins, what a joke

I love far cry, and this game is fun. However the fact it WILL NOT LAUNCH if you're not online and have a ubisoft account, is the absolute killer of any reason to buy this game or any Ubisoft game in the future. I bought this to use on om steam deck while i travel. Didnt know about the mandatory account at the time. Tried to refund when i had less than two hours of play and was denied because i have and the game more than 2 weeks. I recommend never buying another ubisoft on pc while this is required.

Ubisoft Connect makes this game a huge waste, tried going through support today as I hadnt launched the game since 2018 only to be met with "I'd also like to inform you that your Steam account is separate from your game license as your license is tied to your Ubisoft account, so you may use the same Steam account but cannot use your license in multiple Ubisoft accounts." effectively soft-locking me from content I bought and decided to return too, never again.

The Ull fight killed  the game for me.
Ubisoft, I kind of liked the game but you really tried and made it suck eventually.

It plays like every other open world crafting game from the past decade where you play as a primitive hunter and gatherer and must kill large herbivores with well-placed arrows or by sticking a spear. I still liked the setting, but Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is basically the same thing except improved with red vegetation and glowing plants, and more creative freedom because of the sci-fi fantasy setting. Overall, this one is pretty lackluster in the current year, and the story is quite simply "primitive and barebones."

When I played it I liked waving the spear and hunting with a spear, but I couldn't even find anything to do with all the things I hunted and quickly filled up my inventory in normal difficulty, and I didn't look forward to the other grindy elements either. The need to tame beasts to progress the plot looks equally silly and tedious, even if it expands how you hunt, I think they could have just polished the combat so it'd be more fun. The stealth was very rudimentary, and I wasn't a fan of how easy it was to simply crouch walk behind an enemy patrol for 30 seconds and then perform an extremely easy one-button kill from the Assasin's Creed games, and how easy it was to quickly ambush 3 men. Your melee options are very limited and you cannot block, parry, dodge or roll (unlike in nearly any recent Souls-game or 3D action game.) Wolves and other animals move in simple patterns that make it easy to line up headshots, and if you do miss a shot they don't run as far away as in Avatar or provide enough of a challenge. This limitation was partly because this game has a much shorter cull distance, and animals could also very noticeably pop in as you walked a short distance.

Because it's Ubisoft it's also not consumer friendly and despite being 9 years old it still contains Denuvo and needs you to install their 3rd party launcher just to play it in a feeble attempt to steer you toward their own storefront.

However, if you enjoy this then maybe you should play Ubisoft's Avatar game, or better yet "Horizon Zero Dawn" which has nearly everything this game has but is much better executed.  That game has better stealth, visuals, more engaging combat, a bigger sense of mystery and discovery, and a more coherent story. I think for $3 FCP is now a mid-tier budget game and I've enjoyed trying it, but your time is more valuable and I'd recommend instead playing something that takes the concept further.

A fun game but I cannot recommend it for various reasons, mainly having to do with the fact that for some reason the devs really really love unskippable animations:  1) Want to heal your pet while getting mauled by a cave bear? Guess what? When you feed your pet to heal it, there is an unskippable feeding animation. So while you're being chewed on by enemies, you have to sit there and watch your frozen character throw meat up in the air for your pet to playfully catch. How fun! Think the option to disable skinning and scavenging animations disables pet healing animations? Think again! 2) If you accidentally click on a quest icon instead of, say, the icon to upgrade a hut, you have to wait for the quest intro cutscene to finish, which goes on forever, before you get the option to abandon the quest you didn't want to start in the first place. More fun! Attention FarCry developers: the escape key should override whatever is going on, at all times! Oh, and you have the added fun of having only one 'character' save file. So if you want to start fresh, say after coming back to the game after several months, well, you have to overwrite your previous save. Extra fun! (I know on PC you can backup your save file, but you shouldn't have to do that in any game made after the 90s. Multiple saves have been around for decades, but the FarCry developers can't figure out how to implement such a basic feature.) It's a shame, because the game is fun, except for these annoyances that completely ruin the experience.
ILL NEVER UNDERSTAND BEING ABLE TO DOWNLOAD ON STEAM AND THEN NEEDING THE "EA" PROGRAM TO RUN THE GAME. I DO NOT WANT THAT BLOATWARE/SPYWARE ON MY SYSTEM. STOPPPPPPPP

I still liked the setting, but Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is basically the same thing except improved with red vegetation and glowing plants, and more creative freedom because of the sci-fi fantasy setting. Overall, this one is pretty lackluster in the current year, and the story is quite simply "primitive and barebones."

When I played it I liked waving the spear and hunting with a spear, but I couldn't even find anything to do with all the things I hunted and quickly filled up my inventory in normal difficulty, and I didn't look forward to the other grindy elements either. The need to tame beasts to progress the plot looks equally silly and tedious, even if it expands how you hunt, I think they could have just polished the combat so it'd be more fun. The stealth was very rudimentary, and I wasn't a fan of how easy it was to simply crouch walk behind an enemy patrol for 30 seconds and then perform an extremely easy one-button kill from the Assasin's Creed games, and how easy it was to quickly ambush 3 men. Your melee options are very limited and you cannot block, parry, dodge or roll (unlike in nearly any recent Souls-game or 3D action game.) Wolves and other animals move in simple patterns that make it easy to line up headshots, and if you do miss a shot they don't run as far away as in Avatar or provide enough of a challenge. This limitation was partly because this game has a much shorter cull distance, and animals could also very noticeably pop in as you walked a short distance.

Because it's Ubisoft it's also not consumer friendly and despite being 9 years old it still contains Denuvo and needs you to install their 3rd party launcher just to play it in a feeble attempt to steer you toward their own storefront.

However, if you enjoy this then maybe you should play Ubisoft's Avatar game, or better yet "Horizon Zero Dawn" which has nearly everything this game has but is much better executed.  That game has better stealth, visuals, more engaging combat, a bigger sense of mystery and discovery, and a more coherent story. I think for $3 FCP is now a mid-tier budget game and I've enjoyed trying it, but your time is more valuable and I'd recommend instead playing something that takes the concept further.
